status.noData: Add readings to see your status

detail.title: Detailed Statistics
detail.description: This section contains technical information and medical metrics for parents, caregivers, and healthcare providers.
detail.timeInRange: The percentage of time your glucose levels are within the target range (70-180 mg/dL).
detail.avgGlucose: Your average glucose level calculated from all readings in the selected period.
detail.hba1cExplanation: Estimated HbA1c shows your average blood glucose over the past 2-3 months. Target is usually below 7% for most people with diabetes.
detail.gmiExplanation: GMI (Glucose Management Indicator) is calculated from your continuous glucose monitor data and gives a similar picture to HbA1c.
detail.cvExplanation: Coefficient of Variation measures how much your glucose levels vary. Lower is better, with a target below 36%.

tips.title: Tips & Advice
tips.subtitle: Helpful tips for managing your diabetes
tips.disclaimer: These tips are for informational purposes only. Always consult with your healthcare provider before making any changes to your diabetes management plan.

hydration.title: Stay Hydrated
hydration.description: Drink plenty of water throughout the day. Proper hydration helps your kidneys flush out excess sugar through urine and prevents dehydration.

meals.title: Regular Meals
meals.description: Eat regular, balanced meals at consistent times each day. This helps maintain stable blood sugar levels and prevents spikes or crashes.

exercise.title: Daily Exercise
exercise.description: Engage in at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity most days. Exercise helps your body use insulin more effectively and lowers blood sugar.

monitoring.title: Monitor Regularly
monitoring.description: Check your blood sugar levels as recommended by your doctor. Regular monitoring helps you understand how food, activity, and medication affect your levels.

medication.title: Take Medication on Time
medication.description: Always take your diabetes medications as prescribed. Set reminders if needed and never skip doses without consulting your healthcare provider.

sleep.title: Get Quality Sleep
sleep.description: Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep each night. Poor sleep can affect blood sugar levels and insulin sensitivity.

stress.title: Manage Stress
stress.description: Practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or yoga. Chronic stress can raise blood sugar levels through hormones like cortisol.

footcare.title: Care for Your Feet
footcare.description: Check your feet daily for cuts, blisters, or changes. Keep them clean and moisturized. Diabetes can affect circulation and nerve sensitivity in your feet.

emergency.title: Be Prepared for Emergencies
emergency.description: Always carry fast-acting glucose sources (like glucose tablets or juice) for low blood sugar. Wear medical identification and share your emergency plan with family.

support.title: Build Your Support Network
support.description: Connect with family, friends, or diabetes support groups. Emotional support is crucial for managing a chronic condition. Consider joining local or online diabetes communities.

notifications.readingRemindersDescription: Get daily reminders to check your glucose

warnings.lowGlucose: Your current glucose of {{glucose}} mg/dL is low. A bolus is not recommended.
